element_texts.text:
May the 17th 1745
Friday about the rising of the sun we came to sail in Annapolis (unclear) and company with the Schooner Seaflower James Suther Commander. Bound up to the Fort of Anapolis (Droyell?) with the wind about SE and opposite Near Goat Island, which is about a League below the Fort, the wind began to near a head (and?) we was Necessiatated to stand in Near of Land on the Larbord side of the River to a place (called?) the Scotch fort, where Very Unexpectedly and to our Great Surprise, there Lay in ambush an army of French & Indians (that?) were sent from Candady to attack the fort of anapolis having had Inteligence from the (Nuteral?) (unclear) at anapolis (unclear). I was sent an (Express?)
to (unclear) and bring In Continental Expectation of my arrival at anapolis, they had provided them with (unclear) news (balled?) up and hid in the (bushes?) all things Necessary for their (unclear) which was compleated to So much Satisfaction,

perhaps there might be Indians on unclear which if there was he apprehended I was in danger, at his unclear I set down on comings of unclear hatether, which of french and Indians perceiving as they lay in unclear on up Shore, and concluded they should have no better opportunity to  make there unclear assault, haled & unclear In English, unclear Diffinetly, I arose directly and answered them, supposing it might possibly be some of the Natural french, they being all acquainted with the Sehooner?. But I soone found my mistake, for before I had well answered them, they discharged a whole volley of small armes at us, we endeavoured to put unclear about but to no purpose, for by the smoke of their Guns with their continual fiering it was almost start calm, we expected every unclearto be a unclear, but at length with much difficulty put her about, but being entierly becalmed we could by no means Govern with unclear, but where driven with the tider

that I was thoroughly (acquainted?) with the River, and Suspicious those spawn of hell might be Incamped somewere on the River, having had Experience of their manners and Customs in two of there attempts against anapolis Royal before yet Could not pereceive the Least alteration on the shore; of sign of them laying in ambush again for me, even with the assisistance of a good prospect glass, which I made use of at that time on purpose to inspect into that place in particuler above all other parts of the River, being Sensible there was no other place so commodious for there intention, as we are always obliged to go verey near that shore, and espedcially when the wind is contrary. we being at this close on board the shore and almost becalmed, as I was walking the Deck my mate Desired me to sit down, and told me

unclear asshore and began to plunder them, cutting our small sails in pieces with their knives to make snap sacks, and splitting our chests in peices with their hate hitts, & after they had plundred our chests of what was most valuable, they brought their booty unclear our cloaths and whatsoever was light & convenient to be transported on shore, and laid them in a heap, and placed us by them, then cituated themselves in a large circle round us in which situation they cast lotts upon their booty after they had shared their light plunder, we was travelled about four miles up to their General, ans after strict examenation what our cargoe consisted in & we was conveyed to their ground unclear a barn about a mile distance from the fort of anapolis, where we had a unclear hansom reception each man furnished with about three ounces and a half of unclear, without so much as a blanket to unclear us unclear the cold, and for our greater consolation

according to the sitting, sometimes a thirt? Tide, and sometimes stern form a ft, we unclear one cannon and one swivel, and four or five small arms at unclear enemey, but they being so many in number, while some where unclear in launching there unclear rest with out any intermission when continually pouring showers of shott upon us, and kept their own men under cover till they bounded and took us which, was all combated in unclear then ten minuts from the begining of their assault I was affraid the would have taken up the paquet unclear and as providence ordered although the bulletts flew amongst us like hail from the heavens, unclear there was but one man hurt amongst the Sia, and he slightly wound in the back, Even the man at unclear who there was five balls strack the Tiller, I believe there was not two minuts difference between their branding the two vessels, after we was taken and carried ashore with our hand, pinioned fast behind us, they aolled our

information that they had of it before they began their unclear, this day they gave us some virtual, & told us we should have the pleasure of seeing Canady, which they supposed to be one of the most famous slaves in the whole universe.
Sunday the 19th This day they infomed us also of sundrey of their transactions, and how they had sent a letter into the fort to the Governour Maskerrene, which informed him they would consent to a capitulation with him on honourable termes, which the intierly disdained and burnt there letter before there messenger face, & would not treat their General with so much respect as to send him an answer to his proposal, at which he was exceeding disgusted and swore he would have sattisfaction they likwise told us that if the Governour

they gave us nothing either to eat or drink, but complemented us with their usuel complement to prissonners, unclear my fiend, fortune of war, In these comfortable circumstances, each man having his hands fast  penioned ? behind him, we lay down to repose our selves amongst the French soldiers for the first night
Saturday
unclear the 18th. This day we remained in the gaund house amongst the French soldiers, who informed us of their long and tedious journey from Canedy, and what difficultys they had undergon to little or no purpose, they being sent from Caneday in order to take anapolis Rayell, which they declared was impossible for them to accomplish, finding the fort. In so good circumstances, and so much stronger then shat they imagined, By the

to my lodging, there Gaund house, where I found my beding much in the same order as left at my three ounces and half of straw as by this time deminished to about half much. on which I endeavoured to Repose my self in the best manner possible for that night with the rest of my companions & fellow prissonner which was ten in number that belonged to the two schooners after having been put in irons with my unclear who was my Yoak fellow at that time for we not only had our hands pinioned fast behind us. but also coupled together in irons so the one could not so much as move on any occasion whatsoever without his partner.
Monday the 20th This day at about nine of the clock in the forenoon. Came W.m Winnet who pretended much friendship to us, and told me he would be glad to speak with me for he had something of considerable consequence to discover to me in private which I

of anapolis, had not treated their General with so much indifferancey we might probably have been sent to the fort and released from our confinement. about three of the clock in the afternoon the unclear gave order, that I must come before him to be examined concerning my letters the was sent from Boston, In order to be delivered to the Governour and officers of anapolis Royell. and when I was conducted to General he asked me by W. Winnit one of the neutteral french who was then his interprater. what was become of the letters that was sent with me for the fort I desiared  the interprater to tell the General I had sunk them, at which he seemed to be exceeding angrey and told me it would have been a Great sattisfaction to him to have had the unclear of them after having asked me Sundray questions concerning our cargoe, &, I was dismissed and conveyed

the fort was in at that time in order to give the spies true disscription and intiligence of the fortification of anapolis in all its parts. This they practiced for some considerable time together hiding the spies in their cellars unclear day leaft by some accident they should unclear discoverd by the people of anapolis and unclear night demonstrated to them the observation? they had made on the Fort. at length by some means the Governour of anapolis having had information of the spies, and likewise of the treachery of these nutrel french, sent out privatley part of men to the number of about seventy, who took five or six of those traitors the neutrel French, but all the spies escaped. thisa? people beeing at this time confined in the unclear as criminals, was what they demanded in exchange for us, which I was fully satisfied the Governous of anapolis would by no means consent to, as I was at anapolis when those people was brought into the fort prisoners and was fully acquainted with the

verey readyly consented to being exceeding glad to imbrace the oportunity supposing it was something relating to our redemtion, and after having obtained permission from the Gaurd and being loosed from my irons. I walked with him some small distance from the Gaurd house, with my hands fast pinioned behind me and when we was sit down on the ground he told me I might be permitted to send a letter to the chief engineer unclear that was then in anapolis fort. on unclear conditions that if the Governour Maskerrain? would releafe five or six of the nuteral french, unclear was then prissonners in the Fort as criminal having harboured for some considerable time, several of General marains officers that where sent as spies from menus, to inspect into the situation of anapolis fort and not only harbourd unclear, but whent into the fort dayly and wrought as Labourous for the King, that they might therby be fully acquainted in what capacity

letter had been interprated to the General sealed it and gave it to Mr Winnit, who told me he would have it sent to the fort, as soon as possible. So with earnest desires cut word to might meet with success. and impatient cut word an answer, we spent the remainder of the day in our lodging the Gaurd house.
Tuesday 21st
This day at about 4 clock in the afternoon the French priest came to the Gaurd house & brought me a letter the was sent from the Chief Eng Mr Bastide. In answer to out letter sent him the day before. which gave me no encouragment of our speedy exchange. the intent ther of was to this affec. Viz received your, and am sorrey for your cut word fate, but as to your preposel, they cannot be complyed with by any means, cut word people you mentioned in your letter cut word apprehanded as criminals and traitors

whole affaire. and therefore was unclear this could by no means be complied which I told mr Winnit as soon as  he made the perposel. Nevertheless I unclear glad by imbraced the oportunity to send a letter to the Chief Engen. Mr Bastied in expectation at least I should then know my distiny. after having concluded our discourse and I had determined too send to Mr Bastide. we returned into the Gaurd house, when he furnished me with pen ink and paper, and after I had wrote the letter I read it to my companions, and desired there approabal  of the purposel, who being exceeding glad of the opportunity we had to sen to the Fort. told me they hoped it might be a means of our redemtion. Nevertheless we was not without anxious care and concern, being sensible the preposel was so very unreasonable, to demand criminal in exchange for prisoners of war. after

glad it was in his power to contribute anything to our consolation. I told him I was under many obligation for the favours I had already received from him in assisting of me concey my letter to Mr Bastide at the fort, cut word sincerly wished it was in my power to make cut word suitable retaliation. but as it was not I would? always have it in Gratfull remembrance cut word defined him to do me the favour as to let unclear have a shirt which I was in great need of cut word the time. having but one corse shirt & the began cut word be considerably inhabitted with french cut word which our straw was full of at the time. cut word told me he was exceedingly well pleased cut word he hd the opportunity to grathifie me, and in cut word he had but two shirts he would verey freely unclear me have one of them. he promised me also he would unclear us some tabaccoe. and each of us a pipe and cut word . me unclear. which would have been received with cut word thankfulness by us at that time then I cut word capable to express. I told him I should take cut word verey Great favour. and disered him to

to the king of Great Britan, and there fore therefore it is not in the Governours power, nor mine to Releas them by any means, unclear to content your self as much as possible with your present circumstances, for you certainly be redeemed in a short time, unclear cape Britoon is Greatly indebted to us unclear their cartel, and the same treatment you meet with amongst them, they may expect to receive from us without fail, I cut word yours, &, after having unclear the letter and considered then was no other cut word but our being exchanged by Luisbourg, cut word composed our selves in the unclear manner cut word still remaining coupled in Irons, and our hands fast pinioned behind us
Whednesday unclear at about nine of the clock in the afternoon, came Mr Wm Winnit to the Gaurd house and seemed to be verey much concerned for condition, and told me he should be exceeding

here we walked with our hands fast bound behind us and coupled together in irons. then we came to the barn we found a great No. cut word Indians seated in all parts both in and round unclear they placed us in the middle of the barn on the floor, and the Indians & some of the French officers cut word to be verey much engaged in discours cut word sd. we unclear was intierly ignorant of cut word supposed it must be something of considerable consequence. at length them seemed to be something of devision amongst the Indiansand cut word observed to take their guns. but did not in cut word measure aprehend the danger we was in at cut word time for the great dispute they had mongst cut word was in unclear manner we should be distributed cut word the Indians. Some of the Indians claimed a cut word litle to us than they would permit them to have insisting that those that boarded cut word to have the greater share. which was no cut word to the law established by King cut word amongst the Israellites that those which stay by the cut word should share eaquel in the plunder with the

take and order on some gentleman in the cut word for his satisfaction, which he would not cut word of by any means whatsoever, But told me cut word was exceeding welcome where it in his power to do us a Greater favour. Nevertheless he desired me to give him a line or two from under my hand in his recommendation that might be a testimony of his generousitty to us cut word any of our friend in the fort. his request I verey willingly consented to being exceedingly glad it was in my power to do him any favour, and especially to write in his recomandation. after I had wrote he took cut word leave of us and promised he would send the nesseceries without fail. but we never saw cut word benifactor afterwards nor received any of the promised benifits. although we was informed he was sundrey times afterwards amongst the armey. at about six of the clock in the afternoon then came orders from the General that we may be removed to another barn that was about a gun shots distance from the Gaurd house

had been taken, and after what manner, and what treatment they had meet with amongst the Indians, and seemed to be verey well satisfied with his condition the herous could all talk exceeding cut word french and asked me if I could speak french. I told them a little, at which thye was cut word pleased, and aked me several questions cut word told me by no means to be disconted or cut word with mt condition for they would use cut word as a brother and that we should commence our cut word for menus the neat day. They gave me cut word some boilled corn and told me I should live cut word well when we arrived to Canady.
They also asked me sundaey questions concerning their prisioner they had taken on Goat island tole me the disadvantage they laboured cut word before I came to make them understand cut word being intierly ignorant of both the French and Indian tongues when it was time cut word repair to sleep i was conveyed to their Captain cut word when after prayers which they never

thas go forth to was, but as they could not again on with? termes we should be divided. they concluded it was most convenient to shoot us directly and end the dispute. For which reason they took their guns as cut word was informed by the French and Indians afterwards however by divine providence we was preserved and distributed amongst the Tribes of Indians I was led with a string to a camping of unclear, a Nation of Indians whose residence is about three leagues from Quebec I seemed tollerabely well satisfied with my lot. with the confideration that I should live verey near the french, and having been informed they was the most civelised Nation of Indians, when I came to their camp I found four prisoners, Viz one English man and three English Indians that belonged to Captain In. Gorhams? Company, and where taken sometime before on Goat island, that Englishman I had been acquainted with, and after I had asked him some particular questions weither any of them Company was taken besid themselves &, he gave me an acount how long

to march in. at about 1/2 after 5 we began our Journey for menus about 500 in companey french and Indians according to the befor computation I could make and to the number of 200 or upward, marched before us the greater part Indinas we marched in a very irrigular manner in sight cut word anapolis fort about a mile from our camp. During which time they continued disdaining cut word Fort and telling me they would in a verey short time have another flagg hoisted upon cut word Governour maskeren in the circustances cut word then in & as we marched I met with cut word of my accquaintance of the nutrel French cut word seemed to be verey much concerned for my misfortune and I believe would have done nay cut word for me that lay in their power, and others I had been intimatly accquainted with seemed shum me and would by no means come near cut word amongst the which was one Monsieu Dugas cut word I took more particular noctive of them cut word the Rep. he being one that had sailed with  cut word for some considerable time and always pretended to have a great regard for me and often told me that if evet it was in his power to do me

neglected night and morning. I had my hand, bound securly behind me and a string fastned round my middle and placed between two Indians one end of the string being made fast to my right hand bed fellow and the other to my left. So that it was imposible for me to stir without waking my companion. In this misserable condition I lay that night in my new lodgings. having exactly fulfiled the old English proverd and jumpt out of the fryingpan into the fire.
Thirsday 23d
This day at about 5 in the morning we began to pack up our bagage in order for marching I had my hands loosned from behind me after cut word they presented me with a considerable quantity of their bagage to pake up for my load to cut word to menus. They also took my shoes from me & gave me a pair of dear shin mogisons cut word as they wear themselves and told me they was better and much preferable to shoes to

23
safly conduct me through all my dificultyes and good time deliver me out of the hands of those any cut word cruel? and barbarous enemies. at this place we cut words sleves with something to eat . at about 1/2 after 10 we took our leave of the old gentleman and departed, we marched through several small villages of the nautrel French, whom I observed to be overjoyed with the succes cut word general had met with, and I believe would have cut word seen? much more if he had taken the fort. att about 3 of the clock we arrived to the river where we was to cut word over, by this time my feet began to be exceeding cut word sore? not having been used to my new sort of shoes, and ahving walked our a great deal of rough and cut word ground with a large pack on my back cut word we had crossed the river and marched some small cut word distance? we arrived to a house when two roads cut word meet? this place we lais down our packs in order to cut word for the rest of our company, and the General who was behind us. after we had stoped some considerablecut word time? there was added to our number I believe about cut word of the Neutral french. one of which asked me several questions concerning the expedition against cut word Luisbourg?, to all which I endeavoured to answer cut word with? a great deal of care and caution, but gave him

any favour he would exert himself to the utmost of his ability, and especially if ever it was my hand fortune to be taken either by French or Indians, this my great friend meeting of me in the road would not so much as shake hands with me But when I reminded him of his former promises to me left me and would not regard me. So much as to bid me farewell even when the Indians seemed to define him to stop. In this manner I parted with my good friend and never saw him afterwards at about 9 of the clock we stoped at a french house where I had been several times before the old gentleman the master of the house knew me and was moved with compasion to see my miserable estate. he took me by the hand & told me he wished with all his heart it was in his power by any means to release me from the hands, of the sauvages I observed the old gentleman was so much affected for me that he could by no means refrain from weeping and told me also that he hoped that the food God would

to lay down our bagage and make preparation cut word our nights repose, at this place we killed cut word several? unclear for our subsistance for that noght cut word for our journey to menus, every Indian and French man seemed exceedingly imbarrased and cut word much business as they could by any means dispence with, all hands roasting meat in all parts of our camps. the poor cattle was no sooner shot down, even before they where slayed but they came with their knives, and each man cut word his peice when he thought proper without cut word manner of regard either to decency or cut word after they had constrained me to cut word about three times as much as I had any manner of appetite to , my master told me to cut word if I could make me a spoon, and gave me hatchet and told me he would assist me in cut word he said there was nothing more necessary for me to be furnished with in my march, he cut word I quickly obeyed, and finished my spoon with so much disterity, that my master was verey well pleased with me, and told me he hoped I whould make as good a heron as one John Homewell

but gave him no sattusfaction or encouragment of the succes that he hoped the french might meet with, but intierly to the contrary the head Captain of the herus whose name was Vincent. a verey subtil cunning fellow. told the man that was examining of me to forbear, and ask me no more questions of that sort, for he mistrusted i told them these things to discourage them from going Luisbourg to their aid and assistance, and signified I should discourage them in fact if they asked me any more questions when the General came up with us, I observed the neutrel french exceeding attentive to hear & observe the order of the General in transporting of their heavey bagage to menus with their horses & and after he had admonished them of what he called their duty in several respects Viz to be always ready and willing to assit an armey, at any time that coem against anapolis in all that lay in their power, which they seemed to cut word signify? they would always endeavour to conform to whenever? opportunity presented we was marched about half a mile beyond all the houses, where we was ordered

their prejudice or that we might contrive some way for me to make my escape from them by his assistance. but the poor man they censured entirely wrongfully, not being so well acquainted cut word his principles as I was, for I had reasons to believe he had so much affection for the Indians cut word so much good will to the English, that he would sooner have gon five miles to deliver an Englishman into their hand, then one mile release him from them. at about 5 in the morning then came order from the General that we must pack up our bagages in order for marching I was cut word great hopes and expected that my master cut word could? have had compasion on me and lighten my pack for that day as he saw my feet was exceedingly swelled and sore with my carrying a large pack tha day before, but I was disapointted in my expectation,  as our farmishing our selves with provissions at this place for our jorney obliged us to carrey the larger packs at about cut word of the clock we took our departure, we travelled

an English man that had lived with them near thirty years, and was married amongst them and had severel children, this night they placed me between two Indians, with a string round my middle and each end made fast to my companions. this night I had my hands at liberty, as they supposed there was no great danger of my endeavours cut word to make my escape, they being sensible I was verey much fatagued with my carrying a large pack that day, and my feet exceeding sore. Therefore I reposed my self considerably well that night
Friday 24th 1745?
This day early in the morning their came to see me one of the neutrel french named John Prejon? one that I had been before acquainted with but the Indians would not permit him to say but little to me by reason he spoke good English and they was afraid we might talk of something

escape from them, the party of men that was sent by the General returned back in a verey short cut word with an English man that had deserted from cut word Fort of Anapolis. who gave an account the General cut word false Information. For he declared them was cut word English out of the fort but himself which cut word the alarm. I desired liberty to speak with him which they would not consent to by cut word means, nor let me come so near him as to cut word who he was we continued our narch till about cut word before we stoped to refresh our selves.
cut word During? with time there overtook us severel cut word of? the Neutrel French that I knew, some of them cut word me and asked my master if he would cut word me, at which he seemed angry and told them never would but keep me with him as long as cut word lived. as we sat at dinner by the side of a cut word of water the man that has deserted from the Fort of anapolis came up with us and sat down cut word me, and gave me an account of all the unclear cut word the fort in the time of the seige, and that all the gentlemen the fort was in good health & the man I was verey well

verey moderatly at our first setting out what the Indians told me was always their custom when they designed to make out a great cut word day?March, this morning at about 8 of the clock cut word them? ran by us a considerable number of the neutal French, and told us then was English in persuit of us from the fort of anapolis, and cut word asked?how far we suposed the General was a head of us, for they was come with great expedition unclear25? acquaint that general of this afair I observed some was on horse back and other on foot, all cut word forward with all possible expedition to deliver the message to the General. The Indians also began to quicken their pace and told me they would cut word presently have more English prisoners for company for me. we soon overtook the General who sent back a party of men in order to attack the English he had intiligence of. at this time the Indians was exceeding carefull of me and would not by any means trust me to go 5 yards, from cut word without a Gaurd, least I should endeavour to cut word

cut word feet? was so exceeding sor. after we had cut word marched? some considerable distance my master cut word so much compassion on me as to cut cut word a peice of his blanket and wrape about cut word feet, and opened the blisters that was then on my feet almost as big as my thumb. this day was exceeding hot the sin beat upon with so much vehemencey that both the Indians cut word us prisonners was almost melted with the cut word, this day I had the company and conversation of a cape sable Indian called cut word, who had lived six or seven years in cut word and could speak verey good English this man gave me a reguler acount of the situation of Canedy, and told me in what manner he supposed I should be marched cut word, I asked him if he suposed there was cut word any? prospect of my redemtion in a short cut word time?, he told me if it had been my unclear fato? to have been with his nation he believed I should be redeemed in a verey short time.

acquainted with and asked him the reason his leaving the Fort, which I perceived hed not care to tell me by any means, this day we continued on our march till some time after sun set, by which time I was so fatigued that I was almost of the mind I cut word should? be forced entierly to give over, having cut word  a large pack all that day. This night we incamped on the top of a hill by the side of the road. where i slept between two Indians with the heavens over me for my covering and cut word they tied me that night, is what I am cut word unable to give any account of. For I believe before I had layed down four minuts, I was asleep, and never awaked till they called me in the morning to prepare my self for the other days journey.
Saturday the 25th
This day we took our departure verey early in the morning, at my first setting out I could verey hardly stand upon my legs, my

proceed from humaine creatures, they came
to our camp where there was five prisoners.
Took myself and another Englishman, and
(unclear) English Indians, my master told me
come and sit down by him, and to tell yr
of yr prisoners to sit each man close
his master, they came to our camp dancing
yiewlling, and one of yr squaws come to me and
took me by my arm and I suppose bid me come
to, but my master told me to sit still,
& by no means stir out of my place; and
t squaw offend in a very harsh manner
ere was an old Indian in their company yt
he exceeding good French, who came to
Captain of our Indians Viz y herona, and
he fined he would gratifie them so far as
let thm have y pleasure of dancing
round us prisoners, he was obliged to 
speak French, and therefore I had y opportunity to
understand the substance of what he said.
Captain of y herons was a verrey subtle cunning
fellow, and answered to this effect.  Viz

by reason there was six or seven of Nation cut word then prisonerd in Boston, which he told they would endeavour to exchange, as soon as there was any possibility of their cut word exchanged, we arrived at menus at about six of the clock in the afternoon, where we overtook a considerable number of Indians that had gon before us, and several of the French officers and souldiers, at this place we incamped by the side of a small river, I believe there was then in companey about four hundred of Indians and french, but the greater part Indians, by reason the cut word General? and most of the French soldiers had gon some distance before us, at this time there came many of the unclear miemock? unclear Squaw? to see their husbands that had been against cut word anapolis? and to have the pleasur of dareing round the prisoners, which is always their custom at their first reception, after they had been to several of the camps dancing and making the most hellish Naive that is possible

cut word bed fellows with a string round my middle cut word, and slept by the blessing of almighty God cut word well
Sunday the 26
This day we took our departure at about seven of the clock in the morning, my master encouraged me with the telling of me we we should have but a cut word Verey? small march for that day Viz cut word about? three leagus after we took our departure cut word marched by several of the Nuterel French houses the people I observed seemed cut word be exceeding courtious to the Indians & cut word congratulated? their succes and happy cut word and signified it was verey evident cut word God almighty was on their side I cut word verey narrowly their cut word behaviour? towards us prisoners and found cut word was well pleased to see us in such

I am verey sorry you hapned to ask me this favour in perticuler which is the on cut word one you could have asked me and been denied, this meathod and custom you cut word amongst your nation, is intierly contrary to what is allowed or permitted with us, therefore sir as we denie our selves this priveledge, I hope you will be pleased  cut word excuse me, as I am intierly under an obligation to refuse you at this time after they had passed many complements on each side, the old greayheaded Indian took his leave of us and departed, and told his companions they could have cut word no? admittance at our camp, after they cut word were? gone the Captain demonstrated to me what had passed between them, and told me to cut word take? the other prisoner that belonged to our camp cut word which? I did, and told him we took it as a verey cut word grate? favour that he should have so much care of us and desired to be greatfull for it, this night I reposed myself between my two

Monday the 27th
This day we remained in our habitation cut word did little else but eat and drink cut word greater part of the day, which I observed the custom of the Indians, whenever the stop  cut word any place where they can possibly cut word it in their power, either by beging cut word borrowing? or stealing....
TUesday 28th
this day at the Goal the Indians diverting themselves with many sorts of unclear Viz runing wrestling eating and drinking and dancing & this day there came many of teh Neutral french cut word see me, bu I observed the Indians was verey cut word of them, and would not suffer me to cut word with them except I spoke french and cut word that when I spoke to them in french it cut word be in their prefence or I could no cut word that permission.

a condition the greater part of them cut word thought? I must confess sum of them seemed verey much to paty our circumstances, at cutword about? eleven of the clock we arrived to the houses when the French General was and cut word of his officers, who after having passed their usual complements between them cut word selves? and the Indians. they asked us how we did and said they believed the poor unclear was pretty well fatigued with their march and carrying such large pack &, we was order, by the General to a house that I supposed by its accomodations to be a unclear goal. my master informed me we should stop at this place some considerable time. which I was exceedingly glad to hear in hopes I might by some means or other obtain my freedom. at this place we had considering our circumstances indifferent good lodging we had a good flour to lodg on, and as much straw or hay as we thought convenien

endeavour to serve two masters and please them both though I must confess I loved neither of them
June 1st Saturday 1745
This day came to see me Joseph Gautez who I had been well accquainted with at anapolis, and infomed me that they was designed for Capbritone to a fist the french with all expedition which I was verey glad to hear, and hoped I might be either taken or exchanged by the English cut word that means
june the 2d Sunday

This day in the morning the Capt of our Indians, told me I must prepare my self cut word and? go to mass with them, which I presently did as I had not the trouble to shift my self, having but one shirt and that on my cut word back? at about eight or nine of the clock the morning I whent with the Indians. to the

Whedsday 29th
This day we was also at the Goal the Indians was exceedingly imbarrassed and full of buisness, in selling their cut word plunder and seemed verey much cut word distante? with their part, suppasing the cut word had not done them justice.
Thirsday 30th
This day we was also at our habitation the Goal the Indians was dividing of their plunder and selling of their heaves bagage &
the 31st Friday
This day we was dividing of their money and small good, that was light for carrige amongst the Indians. I also understood that I belonged to my two old bed follows the Indians that I lay between the first night that i was with them, and found I must

whednesday the 5th June 1743
This day in the Goal  the Indians was exceeding carefull of me and would not cut word suffer? me out of their sight. nor permit me to speak with any of the French people  cut word Leaft? I should ask them news, or that I should endeavour to make my escape, they also told me that if one of us should cut word make? our escape from them, they would cut word kill? all the rest. I observed that they was cut word more? suspicious of me then of any of the cut word and would not confide in me so fat as to trust me to go to the fountain alone, which was but about a pistol shot from cut word quarter. wheres any of the rest might cut word gone from our quarters for the value of two cut word, and not be asked after, and especially cut word read the Englishman that was teaken on cut word Island that belonged to Capt In. Gorhams? Companey

mass house. but they was not pleased cut word with? my behaviour. Viz I made no use of the cut word holly? water in entering the Church. and cut word likewise? refused to accept of the consecrated cut word bread? when it was offered me. and did not cut word my self as they did. There fore I was cut word excommunicated. and they would not cut word me to enter their Church afterwards.
June the 3 monday
This day the Indians exceeding industrins? in making preparation for their voyague to Luisbourge fixing themselves with provissions and mogisons and all things nesseserey for their interprise
Tuesday the 4th
This day they was also preparcing for Luisburg and the french officers seemed to be exceeding urgent to make all posible dispatch this day I saw my Mr Joseph wear pass by our lodgings but could not be permitted to speak with by any means

cut word asked me if in case I should be willing cut word sell my brother to a stranger for cut word consideration. I told them the case was cut word entierly? different, for they could not cut word suppose? me to be as a brother, nor even as friend, they insisted that I was both, and told me it was always their custom to cut word there prisoners as bretherin and friend and therefore I must endeavour to conform cut word self to their manner and customs, and cut word the futer suppose my self under the dominion of their tribe the herons. and by cut word means pretend to call or suppose my self cut word Englishman, but that I should always cut word reconned and numbred as one of their tribe cut word I thought was verey poor encoutagment cut word my being delivered quickly out of their cut word hands?. But nevertheless I was abliged to cut word submit? my self to the higher powers. and cut word subject? my self to their diferetion after had discoursed some time with Mr Prince

Thirsday 6th
This day I had Intiligence by some of the Neutrel french, that Mr Joseph cut word my mate. and Isaac Prince one of my people. and one Jonathan Rich, that belonged to Capt Sutherland, Master of the other schooner that was taken with us. was bought out of the hands of the Indians by some of the Neutrel french. I was verey joyfull to hear of their good fortune, and hoped I might meet with the like succes at about 10 of the clock in teh morning came to our lodging the man that had bought Isaac Prince out of the hands of the Indians & Isaac with him & told me if there was any possibility for me to be redeemed from the Indians, I might depend he would do his utmost, therefore I preposed terms to my masters, but they would by no means consent ; although the cut word master? came up to 100 pistoles for my redemption

clock in the afternoon in order to sail for cut word place called quebeect about 15 leagues cut word distance? from menus the french General cut word the greater part of his officers imbarqued cut word board the schooner montaque. I was put on cut word guard? gotease schooner. and the greater part of the prisioners. this night we arrived to cut word plan fort? 3 league distance from the enterance of cut word that we took our departure from where we cut word to an anker for that night
Saturday the 8th
This day we come to sail at about 4 clock in teh morning , with a good brease of wind cut word our favour, Joseph Gautez master of schooner that I was on board of, told me I cut word right? depend that he would do all that lay his power for Release me from the Indinas cut word he believed he could prevail with them sell me, but I was intierly disapointed

and disiered he would acquaint the Englishmen? Mr Bastide, adn any of my friends that had it in their power to help forward my redeption, and return the Frenchman thanks for the pains he had taken on my account. they took their leave of cut word and I never saw them afterwards
Friday the 7th
This day at about 8 or nine of the clock there came orders that we must pack up our bagage in order for our departure, cut word there? came many of the Neutrel french to take there leave of the Indians, and wished that God might prosper them in their voyage, and  give them succes. we imbarked on board four vessels at a place called Grand Canard. Viz Goatease schooner. and our two schooners that was taken at anapolis and a sloop that belonged to one Jacques Bomaus? one of the Neutrel French. we Imbarqued at about 2 or three of

would have been more commendable in them have left their careases behind them & cut word brought? their skins at this place we had an acount that the General had received letters from the Governour Masguerin? and hoped they cut word might? be of service to us but was disapointed cut word our expectation
Sunday the 9th 
This day in the morning the French and Indians whent to mass with the neutrel French, all except a few of their number cut word suficient? to guard us prisoners and to make reparation for their march, after they cut word returned from mass there came orders cut word we must pack up our bagage and take cut word our? departure. I asked my master how far cut word supposed we should march that day, they cut word but a small distance and gave me a cut word verey? large pack. we set out on our journey cut word and? marched the day about three leagues

In all the schemes I could project on that purpose for I found it was in vain to cut word any trial, or dependance before we cut word camp? to luisbourg or Canedy. THis day we arrived to Cebecet about 4 of the clock in the afternoon which was about 15 leagues distance from menus about east, at this place the neutrel french came down to the shore and saluted the General and armey with many irregular volleys of small armes, after we had landed there was many of our Indians and the french officier received with great acclamations of joy by the neutrel french, and carried with them to their church where they sung Te cut word for their happy arrivel. at this place there came one of the Neutrel french to the Indians and asked them of their sucees & and how many prisoners they had the Indians gave him an acount and showed him some of us prisoners. he asked them the reason of their bringing of them alive saying he thought

luisbourg, at this place our Indians killed sheep and told what sumtions living I might expect when we arrived to Canedy, and boasted verey much of their libertyes and previledges above any other nation. and told me they cut word in subjection to no king nor prince cut word the universe
Monday the 10th
This day verey early in the morning we began to make preparation for our march, the Indians tols me they was dosigned to march that day to a place called Togmiguish? which wa ninve leagues distance from this place, they told me they preposed cut word when? we arrived to togmeguish to imbarque  vessells and connews and that day would cut word the last days march we should have, they cut word me out with large pack, and we took cut word departure at about 5 in the morning this day we travelled over high mountains

and arrived to a small number of cut word French? houses, where we stopped and refreshed cut word our? selves, the Indians told me that there was other inhabitante, till we came to a cut word place? called Togniguish?, which was about cut word 900? distance, therefore they concluded cut word to? reside at this place for that night. We took up our quarters in a barn where the Indians charged me to repose my self in the best manner i could, in order to cut word prepare? my self for the neat days march, at this place came to see me a french man cut word Chatinif?, who belonged to the armey, and spoke verey good English, he told me his place of residence was at Prenobsquet? Indians at that time in the armey. This man was verey well acquainted in many parts of New England ans asked me after several men & he also gave me an account of their intentions and in what manner they supposed to go to

carrey us to Luisbourg, I was left behind cut word the camps, where thye was killing of cattle cut word laying in a stock of provissions, for our voyage, there manner of curing meate that cut word design to keep any considerable time cut word to cut it in large fletches, and lay it cut word the fire, till it is so smoakadryed, and cut word rosted? that one cannot perceive any manner of moister in it, more then in a chip, this cut word the custom of both french and Indians, cut word they design to carrey their provisions cut word considerable distance
Whenesday the 12?th
this day there arrived a man from Luisbourg cut word had been but twelve days in his passage cut word brought letters to the General of our companey?, to make all possible dispatch to cut word assistance at Luisbourg, and likwise cut word him information, that the English had cut word great progress, and met with great cut word, this New, was intierly concealed from

and low valleys and was verey much cut word fatigued? both Indians and English, with the cut word heat of the sun, that beat upon us with cut word much vehemency, some of the Indians carried concews, was almost melted cut word obliged to gave out before night, our company cut word Indians that I was with, arrived the greater cut word of us to Togmiguish a little while cut word before? sun set. but some gave out and incamp by the way. at this place there lived an cut word old? gentleman that had been a prisoner in queen Ann's war in boston, and spoke verey good english the old gentleman seemed verey kind to me and gave me a piece of cut word and told me he was verey sorrey for our misfortune and wished it was in his power to contributo any thing to our consolation

Tuesday the 11th
This day at Togmeguish the greatest part of our company of Indians whent into the woods in order to make connews

seemed to denote something otherwise, then what the Indians had told me, although cut word when? they was amongst the Indians, they cut word on a chearful contenance to incourage them, but as I had nothing else to imploy my self with, of any considerable consequence cut word inspect into their actions, I made a remark that the french officers I could often cut word see? setting together, and talking so seriously, and with so much concern, that i was fully presuaded In my mind, that they had given the Indians wrong information
thirsday 13th
This day all the armey exceeding buisey making preparation for our voyage to Luisbourg, the Indians imployed in making connews and paddles & and the french In transporting of their Bagage, and all that was heavey carriage on board of the vessels this day then came many horses loaden

the Indians, and turned to quite the cut word revers? by the french officers, to encourage the Indians to continue on their voyage with eagerness, in expectation of cut word great? booty of the spoil of the English, which they supposed to vanguish? intierly at their arrival to luisbourg, and the news passed curant in all the camps cut word the Indians that there was a french fleet arrived to Luisbourg, and had intierly cut off our shiping, and destroyed the greater part of the land armey, and the small number that remained of them had fled into the wood some distance from Luisbourg and in great distress, having nothing to subsist on this many of the Indians told me in disdain, and asked me what I though of our armey at Luisbourg, cut word &? whether I had any hopes of their taking of it at this time, and many other such ridiculous questions, all this I regarded as trifles, and observed the countenance of the french officers, which I conceited

their discourse and for that purpose throed my self in their way, as though I had been gathering of stiks for the fire, and placed my self in such possition, taht I could hear the whole of their discours, and as they passed heard this gentleman bemaining himself cut word said if his aged father and mother was cut word then his concern would be nothing in comparison to what it then was, this I though was a plain confirmation to my opinion and cut word being? fully sattisfied in my mind that the Inglish had the better I returned cut word our camp, and when I saw a convenient opportunity I divulged my mind to my companions, and related to them the observations I had made
fryday the 14th
This day in the morning then came ordering cut word must pack up our bagage and take our departure for Luisbourg the greater part of the cut word Indians imbarked in connew made of bark, some of Elm and sum wite ash, and

with provissions from Quebeect Viz cut word flower meat and biskett and liquor & the french officers, seemed exceeding cut word to make all possible dispatch, and cut word the Indians would be as expeditions as possible in finishing their connew and all their utensiels cut word was necesserey for our voyage, I was cut word much dissatisffied and impatient to hear the truth of the new concerning our cut word forcess? at Luisbourg, and endeavoured by all cut word possion? means to inform my self of it. there was a man in the armey that belonged to Luisbourg an officer, him I observed in perticuler above any of the rest in expectation that as he was an inhanitatn then he would be touched more sensibly then any of the others, either with sorrow or joy, according as the new in reality was and seeing this man walking with another officer and talking verey seriously and with a great deal of concerned I had a great desire to know the substance of

Saturday the 15th of June 1745 This day early in the morning we began to make preperation for our departure the place where we incamped was in a sandy cove, behind a point of land cut word sheltered us from the sea. They supposed it cut word convenient for us, to be as expeditions as cut word possible?, and make the best our way, as we cut word in connews, and could go but slowly cut word imbarqued verey early in the morning, in expectation the General and those behind us could soon overtake us, as soon as we where imbarqued and turned the point. we saw three cut word sail? of sloops but a samll distance from us, cut word made directly for us, there was great cut word disputing? amongst them, some Sd they was French vessells bound for Luisbourg with provissions, and others they was English cut word my? Indian Master asked me my opinion of them cut word told him I could not tell what they was cut word I believed they was English, and I cut word thought? knew one of them which was Capt Donhahew?

so large that sum of them would carrey cut word verey? comfortably fourteen men, and their cut word bagage? so that all of them could paddle or row, cut word discommoding each other in the least. the cut word Indians Viz those that lives reounf the bay cut word fondy, and on Cape Sable Shore imbarques greater part in two shallops and the cut word on board two vessells , a sloop and a schooner all excepting about thirty, that has cut word before us as spies. and a few of the French officers, and their priest, which was with the Canedy Indians, us prisoners was chieply cut word our respective masters. we that was imbarque in connews, took our departure from cut word Togmiguish? before those on board the vessel came to sail after we had paddled about two or three cut word league? we had intiligence that some of the vessells had ram aground. there fore they concluded it was best for us to go on shore, and cut word for the General, which we did. and stoped cut word there? that night.

sloops seeing of us gathered together after cut word such? a manner, and concluded we would not continue on our course, put about and stood towards us, and signified they had a mind cut word to? speak with us, which they presently Did, for they seeing we would by no means cut word by them and they being verey near cut word, down comes the french colours on one side cut word up the English on the other and knocked cut word their portes. and almost in the twinkle of an eye, they gave us three or four cannon shott came exceeding near us, that made [[cut word[[ water of a foam in the middle of us, the Indians seeing this there was a great confusion amongst them. he was the best cut word that could get on shore first the bullet continued flying amongst us, but by bad fortune they all escaped safe on shore and never a man hurt, we halled our connews up cut word a sea wall the sloops stood near cut word shore and came to an anker, and fiered

sloop, we continued our course along cut word shore?about 200 of us in company and brought the sloops to bear almost a stern of us, one the sloops changed her course and stood cut word the General, who was then about two leagues a stern of us, the other two stood for us cut word overhalled us considerably. we diseerned cut word colours verey plain, and saw they cut word under french coleurs, this encouraged them Indians verey much and they concluded they was canedy sloops bound for Luisbourg, but I was fully perswaded? to the contrary, and told them I believed they would find them cut word mistaken, we was abliged to kep the shore on bord in our connew. and in going round a large cove the sloops shott a head if us & stood in by a point, so that we could not continue on our course, without their speaking with us by an means, this put them on consideration, what was best to be done some concluded it was best for us to continue on our course, others to go on shore

take the privatear, if they had a few cannon but nevertheless if it continued calm, they would soon take her with small armes for they was then in chase of her with all four of their vessells, and intend cut word board her the two sloops that was with cut word hearing the continual fireing come to cut word, and made all possible expedetion to cut word other aistance, as soon as they saw sloops make towards the General the french officers cut word that? was with us , and likwise the Indians, cut word their countenances cut word exactly imetated great king of Babylon and said one to cut word mother? that they was verey much concerned at  cut word what? they feared would be the event, for cut word was sensible there would be much cut word blood? shed if they was not all destroyed soon as the French General saw the other cut word sloop, he gave order to make for the cut word with all possible expedition, the cut word sloops? gave chase and followed them.

verey briskly upon us, but we being behind the sea wall it was to no purpose for as soon as they saw the flash of a cut word Cannon? they tumbled, as quick as though they have been shoot down. the Indians lay seatered along shore some considerable distance and to show there great courage, would somtimes crawl from behind the sea wall, and hoops and yell, and make the most hellish cut word noises? that is possible to proceed from humain creatures. at length there came a ball, that passed through one of their bodys and carried part of his powder horn, that hung by his side with it. the sloop that stood back for the general, and those that was behind us, began to fire verey briefly the Indians began to much concerned for the general, and sent messenger back by land to inspect how affair stood. who returned in verey short time and gave inteligence, that they would soon

to Togmeguish, nor hear any news from the General this night I sought for an opportunity to make my escapr, but the Indians kept cut word good a watch I found it would be but cut word to make the attempt
Sunday the 16
This day early in the morning we began to transport our connews, and bagage over the land about a league. into the harbour of Togmeguish we had inteligence that the General, and all that was with him, was cut word and that never a man was hurt in all cut word engagement, nor never a shott hit cut word of their vessells, this news filled the hearts of all the French and Indians with joy. but cut word did not believe it was possible when the  cut word engagement? continued from about  9 of the clock in the morning till 4 in the afternoon, we arrived cut word the place where the General was about ten of clock in the forenoon, where they had halled all cut word of their vessels ashore in a crick and

verey clost but by the help of their cut word they made their escape, and arrived safe into their lurking place, a small crick where the sloops could not follow the sloops followed clost in to the mouth of the crick, and came to an anker, so that they could by no means come out when we saw the course was clear we embarqued in our connews. In order to return to Togmiguish in expectation the General and all that was with him, was either taken or killed when we came in sight of the Harbour, we found the Three sail of privetear, where come to ankerin the entrance, and we could not by any means pass without being exposed to the danger of their cannon, and we was abliged to go round to another place and transport our connews by land into the harbour, this night we incamped at the head of a small crick and could not arrive

falling trees round their camps. In expectation of the English, comming to attack them on shore, then was also spies cut word our camp, continually passing and cut word repassing? to inspect weither there was any danger of their landing to attack cut word which the French and Indians told me they wished they would attempt & I should soon have more of my countrymen in there camps with me for companye
Whednesday the 19th
This day we had an account, that the English vessells was augmented to the number of five or six, and they began to be concerned, and affraid they should cut word intierly obstructed in their voyage to Luisbourg
Thirsday the 20th
This day the General sent for the heads of our camps of Indians to com to their

Incamped by them, I discoursed with some cut word of? the prisoners, that had been on board the French vessells in the engagement who gave me a regular account of what had passed on board and told me there was not a man killed nor wounded. This day we was imployed in making preparation for our lodging &c, and many of the Indians and French disputing what was the most purdent meathod, they could take to commence their second attempt for Luisbourg
Monday the 17
This day the French and Indians verey cut word busy? in situating our selves, in the most commodious manner to defend themselves in case the English landed. This day we had inteligence, there was another sloop arrived and come to an anker with the other three
Tuesday the 18th
This day the French and Indians Imployed

but could not prevail with them to go to Luisbourg by any means, when the Indians had returned to our camp, they gave me an account of what had passed, and told me cut word acquaint my commerads, that we should cut word commence? our jorney, for Canedy that cut word Day?, and by no means to make our selves cut word in any? ways uneasey or disconted, for is was best thing that could happen, for us cut word go to Canedy, for several reasons, one cut word was? that id in case they whent to Luisbourg. and the English was like to have better of them, it was verey probable they should knock us in head, and take of our cut word which they told me, was often their cut word, when they was persued by the English cut word their prisoners might be no hindrance cut word them in their flight, at about noon cut word set out on our journey, for the Bay Verd cut word 70 in comapney. This day we travelledcut word a great deal of rough and bad travelling

counsell, that was then held at the General camp, and told them they preposed to make a second attempt for Luisbourg and in what manner he preposed to cut word take? their departure and not be mistreested? by the English Privatears. VIz. That he designed to take their departure, a little after dark in connews, and that he should Imploy, three or four of the neutrel french to be continually stirring the fire, in all parts of the camps that they might therby amuse the English, and make them believe they was at the camps, and in the mean time paddle easseyly under the shore and slip by the privetears without being discovered the herous and sum of the Ebeniqui? Indians would not consent to go to Luisbourg by any means but told the General, as they had already made an attempt, and had been obstructed, they insisted on going to Canedy. The General used many arguments

was to pass over a crick that was in our way, and he expected we should be obstructed by the tide if we was not verey expeditions when we came to the crick which was about 8 in the morning, we found the watter amost up to our chins, and some was obliged to swim. This day at 12 of the clock my master gave cut word for my dinner, about one third part of dryed eall. which seemed to be at that time the sweetest morsel that ever I tasted in the whole course of my life. This day we arrived to the Bay Verd, at about 6 at night. was verey much fatigued with our days march both Indians and English having travelled 7 leagues over extraordinary bad travelling we was that day abliged several times to help one another out of the mud. This night the french people at the Bay Verd gave me something to eat and some tabacoe &c
Saturday the 23d
This day there came one of the neutrel french

and over marshes and cricks, and flatts &c. Somtimes almost up to our middles, in mud cut word and water. we travelled about four leagues and incamped by the side of a large marsh
Friday 21st
This day we travelled, chiefly along shore over clifts of rocks, sands &c This day we was exceeding hungry and little or nothing to eat we was obliged to take the bark off birtch Trees and serape the inside of it, with our knives and eat it for our subsistance. This night we arrived to a place where we found a few clambs, and catched a few small fishes, this day we marched about 9 leagues and incamped by the sea side.
Saturday the 22d
This day my Indian master gave me a small cake, In the morning before we began our march and told me I must expect to march that morning verey fast by reason?

supposed we should be marching to Canedy &c many of the Neutrel French came to see us about non that I had been acquainted with
Tuesday the 25th
This day the Indians called a counsell to consider, wether it was most convenient to go to the river of Saint Johns. in the schooner montague, that I was taken in Cut word and? was then at that place. or wether it was best for us to go by land after many disputes amongst them they concluded it was best to go by land. the Indians that I belonged to after they had drwan up conclusion amongst themselves they explaind  ut word affair to me at which I told them I cut word verey sorrow, for I dreaded the thoughts cut word Travelling by land, as I had already experienced so much of the difficulty therof
the 26th Whensday
This day the schooner montague sailed cut word the river of Saint Johns, then was on board

an inhabitant at the Bay Verd, named Morrisse? and told me he would endeavour to purchase me out of the hands of the Indians if he was able but he pleaded poverty and told me he would send to his brother that lived at Bon Basan, and he made no doubt. But he would purchase my redemtion if there was any possibillity we took our departure at about 6 in the morning for Bon Basan being exceeding short of provisions when we arrived we found provissions. exceeding searce and dear. This day we travelled about 6 leagues and incamped at Sicconmeetaw? near the mass flouse
Monday the 24th
This day our Indians preparing provisions necessarey for our jorney and many matterials they gave me an account of the rivers and ponds we shouls meet with in our way and in how long a time they
